comments: Expansion in any base b of 1/(b^3-1). E.g. 1/7 in base 2, 1/26 in base 3, 1/63 in base 4, etc. - _Franklin T. Adams-Watters_, Nov 07 2006a(n) = A130196(n) - A131534(n). [From _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Nov 12 2009]
formula: G.f.: x^2/(1-x^3). a(n) = -(1/2)((-1)^Floor[(2n-1)/3]+(-1)^Floor[(2n+1)/3]) - Mario Catalani (mario.catalani(AT)unito.it), Jan 07 2003a(n) = 2/3*{cos[2*(n+1)*Pi/3]+1/2} with n>=0 a(n) = 1-[(n+1)^2 mod 3] with n>=0 a(n) = 1/9*{4*(n mod 3)-2*[(n+1) mod 3]+[(n+2) mod 3] with n>=0 - _Paolo P. Lava_, Nov 29 2006a(n) = ((n+2) mod 3) mod 2. Also: a(n) = 1/2*(1-(-1)^(n+floor((n+2)/3))). - _Hieronymus Fischer_, May 29 2007a(n) = (1+(-1)^Fib(n+1))/2, where Fib(n) = A000045(n). - _Hieronymus Fischer_, Jun 14 2007a(n) = (n^5-n^2) mod 3. - _Gary Detlefs_, Mar 20 2010a(n) = {(-1)^[a(n-1)+a(n-2)] +1}/2 starting from n=3. - _Adriano Caroli_, Nov 21 2010a(n) = 1- Fibonacci(n+1) mod 2. - _Gary Detlefs_, Dec 26 2010a(n) = floor((n+1)/3)-floor(n/3). - _Tani Akinari_, Oct 22 2012
crossrefs: Partial sums are given by A002264(n+1).
author: _N. J. A. Sloane_.
